content.description: Climb up the shattered seam. Route has very good flow and thus would be a good warm-up or cool down route.
content.protection: 5 bolts and chain anchor
content.location: Left side of the wall, route just to the left of the short rock stump that provides the best seat in the house. The pillar has a shattered seam.

content.description: Climb the dihedral and obvious thin crack, then traverse out left below the roof to finish on Nice Dreams. No crack climbing really necessary, edging and stemming is plentiful. The traverse left comes sooner than you might think, and the final bolted bit is the technical crux.
content.protection: Nuts and small-medium cams for the first bit. You might find one or two placements for a #1. Then one bolt and a chain anchor.
content.location: The obvious corner below the roof.

content.description: Uneventful. Crackly holds. A little bit of movement at the 3rd bolt that’s further to the left and forces you onto the arete. 5th bolt is hidden.
content.protection: 5 bolts and chain anchor
content.location: On its own at a curve in the trail between Unfinished Business and the Nice Dreams/Ill-Advised Crossover pillar. Climb aboard a large platform to get to the belay and start of the route.

climbs.name: Unfinished Business
climbs.fa: Elisa Weinman, Kevin Pogue, Barbara Jones  June 1996 (Yoder 2008 Guide)

content.description: Steep face climbing past 5 bolts to a chain anchor. Small crimps, balanced face moves and awkward bolt placements make for interesting climbing. Move quickly and avoid the pump.
content.protection: Quickdraws: 5. Chains can be accessed from the large bench on which Edge of Mistakes tops out on, if you would rather TR.
content.location: The next route left of Edge of Mistakes. Starts on a short bench about 6 feet above the trail.

content.description: The crux of route is the first move that is pretty fun. After that it is pretty easy.
content.protection: Takes small/medium nuts and cams to 2".
content.location: To far left of the wall. Just right of Lady in Red.

content.description: Short route with a big bench before the chains.
content.protection: Takes small/medium nuts and cams to 1".

content.description: Positive crimpers and good feet will help you up this vertical face
content.protection: 6 bolts
content.location: Just left of Scissor Man

content.description: Tricky moves between the first couple of bolts yield to much easier climbing to the chains.  A little sporty between some of the bolts (guidebook gives it a PG rating), but the climbing is very straightforward and on jugs at that point.
content.protection: 6 bolts
content.location: On the exposed arete and face in the middle of the wall, to the right of Little Book of Lies

content.description:
Easy moves up to a 10' finger crack, ending at a roof. Escape the roof to your right using the obvious rail and continue traversing right, passing the last two bolts of the (upper)

Edge of Mistakes

crack. Finish at chains just above a small gravely ledge. This route is the same as

Ill-Advised Crossover,

except this gains the roof via the crack instead of the arete.

The 6' crack eats BD #0.3's and the top of

Edge of Mistakes

will take a BD #0.4, or perhaps slightly bigger.

According to

Frenchman Coulee

(4th ed): escaping the roof left and ending on chains of

Nice Dreams

, is called

Up In Smoke

(5.7).
content.protection: Gear to BD 0.4 or equivalent
content.location:
Zig Zag wall- to the left of

Edge of Mistakes

and to the right of

Nice Dreams

and

Ill-Advised Crossover.

content.description: Climbing a pillar face, somewhat similar to Scissor Man, but more work finding the holds. Fun.
content.protection: 6 bolts and anchors.
content.location: Second in sport route on the leftside of Zig Zag, next to Scissor Man.

climbs.name: Scissor Man
climbs.fa: Jim Yoder, Bill Robins, Marlene Ford

content.description: Climbs an orange pillar with holds all the way.
content.protection: 6 bolts & anchors.
content.location: First sport route on the left of the Zig Zag wall.

content.description: Short climb that ends under a roof. Incut holds are plentiful but require some reachy moves. Crux is moving back left with a wide foot after the third or so bolt.
content.protection: Four clips and chain anchors
content.location: On the pillar just to the right of the large ledge.  Rock is greyish.

climbs.name: One of These Days (AKA Mohel With A Dull Knife)

content.description:
The clean looking crack on the left side of the crag.

The route starts with three bolts and then continues up the tight hand and finger crack, past one more bolt and ends at chains to the right.
content.protection:
Four bolts and cams to 2"

Or if you're looking for a bolt skipping challange this route can go completely on gear. A good piece right off the deck brings you to thin tiny nut and cam protected seams.

RP's and small cams up to #2 BD
content.location: Left side of the Zig Zag wall

content.description: Short route featuring big moves with positive holds on the arete, and then past the roof to the top.
content.protection: 5 bolts. Chains at the top.
content.location: The bolted route just to the left of the prominant roof and "up in smoke." This route shares the start with "ill-advised crossover."

content.description: 7 bolts on the face of the arete with bright colored lichen between "Tank Target" and "One of these Days". Well protected with easy clips along the way.
content.protection: 7 bolts solidly placed for easy clipping.

content.description: 2 bolts protect the opening moves on the face. Step slightly right to gain the shallow arete' and crimp past 3 more bolts with the occasional jug. Fun movement. Not as closely bolted as its neighbors but still totally safe. One of 8 newer routes at Zig-Zag.
content.protection: 5 well-spaced bolts, 2 bolt anchor with chains.

climbs.name: Love in the Time of COVID
climbs.fa: First recorded by Justin Pucci and Becky Holston - May 2020

content.description:
Begin this route with some fun face climbing up through the shallow portion of the offwidth before getting a knee or hip into the crack. Make your way through a bulge and then into a cozy, yet cruxy flaring pod that abruptly turns right forming a small roof to overcome. Once out of the pod, follow the crack up to an awesome squeeze chimney that takes you over the top of the column. This one seems body-size dependent based on mine and my partner’s experience. Some may find the pod to be the crux, while others may struggle more with the squeeze chimney.

There is some loose rock on this route, but nothing out of the ordinary for Vantage. Using the face features surrounding the crack will feel like 5.8-5.9, but staying in the crack will get you a 5.10a.

Right now, the best way to anchor is to redirect the rope through a BD #3 in the corner crack above and to the back of the column and then run through the chains at the top of The Jagged Edge 5.7.

Ultimately, chains need to be installed on the right wall directly over the route for a less complicated rope situation.
content.protection: Gear from 3-12”. Use BD #3-8 cams or equivalent.
content.location: The obvious wide crack on the right side of the column on which The Jagged Edge 5.7 is found.

climbs.name: Little Book of Lies
climbs.fa: Bill Robins, Jim Yoder, JP Banville, Marlene Ford 1998

content.description:
Stem up a corner using holds on both face and in the corners. Ends at chains.

The book mentions three fixed pins; these no longer exist.
content.protection:
5 bolts + optional piece before 2nd bolt

Or (gear-only): Small chocks, gear to about 1
content.location: Stem box to the chains immediately to the right of Group Therapy

content.description: Decent crack from finger to O/W that takes pro well. Little shelves on face.
content.protection: Standard rack. Chains to the right below grassy ledge.
content.location: Left end of Zigzag next to Tank Target.

content.description: If you don't like ripping out pro, consider top-roping this crack from Scissor Man (5.9s).
content.protection: Gear to 4"
content.location: Right of Scissor Man

content.description: An asthetic and sloping crack with lots of shelves
content.protection: Standard Rack. Chains on Secret Passage.
content.location: Pretty much dead center on Zigzag Wall

content.description: Fun arete and face climb.  Best to move quickly past the first clip.
content.protection: Six clips and chain anchor.
content.location: the most righthand bolted line on the wall.

content.description: Climb directly up the arete to the left side of the prominant roof. Traverse right directly beneath the roof, then climb straight up to the top. Beware the swing potential.
content.protection: 4 bolts on left up the arete, optional 0.3 cam on traverse, then 2 more bolts before the anchors.
content.location: Look for the prominant roof near the first trail on the right side of the zig-zag wall. Climb is located to the right of "nice dreams" and to the left of orange kist / edge of mistakes.

content.description: A chossy little chimney, but fun.
content.protection: Takes small/medium nuts and cams to 2".

climbs.name: Group Therapy
climbs.fa: FA: Marlene Ford, Ryan Spence, JP Banville, Jim Yoder, Bill Robbins  September 1998

content.description: Tricky crimper moves down low bring you around the arete and onto steep, but easier climbing to the anchor.
content.protection: 8 bolts
content.location: In the middle of the wall, left of the stemming crack Little Book of Lies

content.description:
A Vantage rarity - an easy trad route of decent quality! It's got thirty feet of thin crack, then two clips on left.  No jamming required, just stemming and edge climbing.

As of 2017, this route was extended by adding a bolt off the final ledge and a 2 bolt anchor that lowers directly back to the base of the route. No more rope drag when lowering or grassy ledge scrambling required to access the anchor.
content.protection: Takes small/medium nuts and cams to 2", then 3 bolts and permadraw anchor. Or lead it all on gear if you're up for it. Crack has some flaky parts but also enough solid sections to protect fine.
content.location: Thin crack in corner immediately left of Orangekist. Once onto the ledge at the top, the anchor rings are up and left.

content.description: An enjoyable and sustained 5.9 climb with small holds right where you want them, and decent clipping stances. Taller than most climbs on this wall
content.protection: 11 bolts, with chains on top.
content.location: Look for the well-bolted route with small holds, and orange lichen.

content.description:
A semi-rotten hand crack with ample face-holds transitions to a finger/tips crack. The rock quality improves dramatically about half way up before an awesome lieback sequence (crux). Rock quality suddenly deteriorates before topping out, so climb delicately and watch out for some death blocks a little bigger than an end table. They can be avoided, but be really careful.

Don't pass up any opportunities for good gear down low on this route. There are solid placements there, but take extra care to ensure you find them! You're probably not going to fall because of the difficulty of the moves, but a fall due to a hold exploding is very realistic.

Don't let this detract you from the climb- it's not amazing, but def worth doing for the lieback sequence up top.

GEAR BELAY: the gear belay is on the climbers left about 2' below the mesa top. Bring a #4 and a 0.5 for sure; I also plugged an offset 0.5/0.75 BD cam adjacent/right of the 0.5 in the same slot. See pic- it's really your only option, otherwise I wouldn't spray so much gear beta.
content.protection:
>Singles #0.2, #0.3, #1, #3, #4 for gear anchor

>>Doubles: #0.4, #0.5, #0.75, #2*.

>>>If you own an offset #0.5/0.75 (purple/green), bring it for the anchor.

Triples of #2 might be nice if you want to sew it up like I did because of the rock quality. I had to get more creative without a third, but it was fine.
content.location: The crack climb two cracks right of Jagged Edge. It's the next crack past the obvious offwidth.

content.description: Immediately left of "Mr. Nice Guy". Pulls through the short roof on small holds and veers slightly right onto easier face climbing. One of 8 new routes at Zig-Zag wall.
content.protection: 5 bolts. Optional .5 cam above the 2nd bolt.

climbs.name: The Beautiful Serpent Lied to Me
climbs.fa: First recorded by Justin Pucci and Becky Holston - May 2020

content.description:
This route follows a beautiful and curvy crack to the top of the Jagged Edge column. The route begins with an interesting set of face moves to get over a bulge that’s in your face from the start. Once you’re able to get into the crack, you’ll find that it’s width varies as it curves back and forth up the column. This makes for some interesting mini-cruxes that will eventually lead you to wider climbing with a fun top out move.

There is a lot of loose rock on this route that tempts you as face holds offering an alternative to the sting of the offwidth, but it’s best to stay in the crack not just from a purist perspective, but also for safety. Using the face throughout the climb will result in a 5.7 rating, while you will get a 5.9 from staying in the crack.

Right now, the best way to anchor is to redirect the rope through a BD #3 in the corner crack above and to the back of the column and then run through the chains at the top of The Jagged Edge 5.7.

Ultimately, chains need to be installed on the left wall directly over the route for a less complicated rope situation.
content.protection: Gear from 3-12”. Use BD #3-8 cams or equivalent. Big bros dont work well in this crack given it’s constant change in width.
content.location: The obvious wide crack on the left side of the column on which The Jagged Edge 5.7 is found.

content.description: Arete climbing with some strange maneuvering. Not much on the face except some bolts.
content.protection: 10 bolts and anchor
content.location: Pillar on the left side of the wall graffiteed on the bottom with a scarlet "A". The anchor is not visible from the ground.

content.description:
Climb through a few constrictions and bulges with fun movement to the flaring chimney crux. The constrictions that are at the top and the bottom of this chimney section were all that were protectable with my gear set from micros to Merlin #8. It may take a Merlin #10 or a gold Big Bro #5, but I just ran it out. Pop up onto the shelf above the last constriction and climb the final 20-30 feet of low 5th class to a top-out with a great view. Walk off to the left.

There is no record of this being climbed in the past, but if you have any info on prior ascents, the first ascentionists, or the original name for the route, then please let me know and I will update this page. Thanks!
content.protection: Gear to 9”.
content.location: Look for the obvious wide crack between La Llarona 5.7 and Secret Passage 5.10a (between #10 and #11 on page 54-55 of the newest guidebook).
